content: The Act may be cited as the "Medicare Diabetes Self-Management Training Act of 2007". Key findings are also included in the Act. Diabetes is a major public health threat in the United States, with 21 million people currently living with the disease and 54 million at risk of developing it. It is the 6th leading cause of death, with the prevalence of the most common type tripling in the last 30 years. The prevalence of the most common type of diabetes has tripled in the last 30 years, with approximately 2,200 new diagnoses each day. Diabetes self-management training, also known as diabetes education, provides critical knowledge and skills to help patients effectively manage their diabetes. A certified diabetes educator, such as a nurse, dietitian, or pharmacist, specializes in assisting individuals with diabetes in developing necessary self-management skills. Diabetes self-management training, provided by certified diabetes educators, helps individuals with diabetes develop skills to stay healthy and prevent complications. Studies have shown its effectiveness in reducing risks associated with diabetes. Participants at increased risk of developing type 2 diabetes who made lifestyle changes reduced their risk by 58%. The intervention was particularly effective for those aged 60 and older, reducing diabetes development by 71%. Studies show that patients under the care of a certified diabetes educator have better control of their diabetes and improved health status. Lifestyle changes taught by certified diabetes educators can lead to better glycemic control and reduced complications from diabetes. Evidence suggests that proper medical treatment and active self-management can prevent serious medical complications caused by diabetes by up to 90% (blindness), 85% (amputations), and 50% (heart disease and stroke). There are over 20,000 diabetes educators in the United States, most of whom are certified. There are over 20,000 certified diabetes educators in the United States, credentialed by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators. Eligibility for certification requires specific health care credentials and professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training. Diabetes educators certified by the National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators, with years of experience in diabetes self-management training, are uniquely qualified to provide training under the Medicare program. Certified diabetes educators recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. Certified diabetes educators are now recognized as certified providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. The term 'certified diabetes educator' is defined as an individual licensed or registered as a health care professional specializing in teaching individuals with diabetes. Certified diabetes educators are recognized as providers for Medicare diabetes outpatient self-management training services. They must specialize in teaching individuals with diabetes and be certified by a recognized certifying body. Certified diabetes educators must be certified by a recognized certifying body authorized by the Secretary to grant certification for diabetes educators. The National Certification Board for Diabetes Educators or a certifying body for diabetes educators must be incorporated and registered in the United States. Certification requires a qualifying credential in a specified health care profession and professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training. The individual seeking certification must have professional practice experience in diabetes self-management training, pass a national certification examination, and renew certification periodically. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study to identify barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. This includes economic and geographic barriers, availability of referrals, and access to qualified providers. A report must be submitted within 1 year of the enactment of this Act. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on barriers for Medicare beneficiaries with diabetes in accessing self-management training services. A report must be submitted to Congress within 1 year. The Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will develop recommendations on effective outreach methods for educating primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of healthcare. The Director of the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality will submit a report to Congress on recommendations for educating primary care physicians and the public about the benefits of diabetes self-management training. The amendments apply to diabetes outpatient self-management training services from the first day of the first calendar year. The amendments apply to diabetes outpatient self-management training services from the first day of the first calendar year that is at least 6 months after the date of the enactment of this Act.
